vocabURI="http://lod.data-archive.ac.uk/skoshasset/a79b74cd-ce2a-435a-9250-ad5453874690">ZIMBABWE</keyword>         <topcClas>Economic conditions and indicators - Economics</topcClas>       </subject>       <abstract><p>Abstract copyright UK Data Service and data collection copyright owner.</p>The <i>United Nations Industrial Development Organization (UNIDO) Industrial Statistics Databases</i> contain data broken down by country, industry and year for the following variables (units in brackets):<ul><li>number of establishments (number)</li><li>employment (number)</li><li>wages and salaries (current national currency and US dollars)</li><li>output (current national currency and US dollars) </li><li>value added (current prices, national currency and US dollars)</li><li>gross fixed capital formation (current national currency and US dollars)</li><li>number of female employees (number)</li><li>index of industrial production (INDSTAT3 only) (1995 = 100)</li></ul>All value data are presented in national currency and US dollar values at current prices. UNIDO converts the data from national currency into current U.S. dollars using the average period exchange rates as given in the IMF International Financial Statistics (IFS) under series rf. <br> <br> The databanks are built around the International Standard Industries Classification (ISIC) code system, which classifies industry broadly along product lines (such as food, textiles, iron and steel). The ISIC code is covers all areas of economic activity but the UNIDO databanks only relate to the manufacturing section of the code. The code is organised hierarchically with each level containing an increasing level of detail. For example, manufacturing is subdivided into around 20 categories at the 2 digit level, 30 categories at the 3 digit level and 81 categories at the 4 digit level. ISIC levels beyond 4 have been discontinued. See the <a class="external" href="http://unstats.un.org/unsd/cr/registry/default.asp?Lg=1" title="UN Statistical Divisions's Classifications Registry">UN Statistical Divisions's Classifications Registry</a> for further detailed information on ISIC code system. <br> <br> UNIDO currently produces the following Industrial Statistics Databases:<ul><li>INDSTAT4 - in this database, data are arranged at both 3 and 4-digit level of ISIC All Economic Activities Revision 3, and at the 4-digit level, Revision 2</li><li>INDSTAT2 - in this database, data are arranged at the 2-digit level of ISIC All Economic Activities Revision 3. Data are presented in the same format as INDSTAT4, together with metadata information</li></ul>INDSTAT2 is derived from the two pre-existing databases INDSTAT3 Rev 2 (now discontinued) and INDSTAT4 by ISIC Rev2 and Rev3. INDSTAT2 combines historical time series data from 1963 onwards for over 160 countries and is the largest industrial statistics database of its kind. Unlike others presented by different classification standards for different time periods, INDSTAT2 provides data by a single classification standard for more than 40 years, which makes it particularly valuable for long-term structural analysis. As with INDSTAT4, INDSTAT2 presents data for seven principle indicators (number of establishments, employment, wages and salaries, output, value added, gross fixed capital formation and number of female employees).<br> <br> </abstract>       <abstract><B>Main Topics</B>:<br><ul><li>aerospace industry</li><li>agricultural industries</li><li>agroindustry</li><li>chemical industry</li><li>construction industry</li><li>consumption</li><li>consumption (economics)</li><li>dairy industry</li><li>dairy products industry</li><li>econometrics</li><li>economic analysis</li><li>economic forecasting</li><li>electronic industries</li><li>electronics industry</li><li>employment</li><li>employment (economic theory)</li><li>energy industries</li><li>food industry</li><li>food industry and trade</li><li>full employment</li><li>industrial development</li><li>industrial economics</li><li>industrial efficiency</li><li>industrial location</li><li>industrial organisation (economic theory)</li><li>industrial production</li><li>industrial productivity</li><li>industrial statistics</li><li>industries</li><li>industry</li><li>international division of labour</li><li>labour productivity</li><li>labour intensity</li><li>macroeconomics</li><li>manufacturing industries</li><li>manufacturing industry</li><li>metal industry</li><li>metal trade</li><li>national accounting</li><li>national income/accounting</li><li>part-time employment</li><li>power industry</li><li>shipbuilding industry</li><li>socio-economic indicators</li><li>textile industry</li><li>unemployment</li><li>women's employment</li><li>women's unemployment</li></ul></abstract>       <sumDscr>         <timePrd>The <i>UNIDO Industrial Statistics Databases</i> contains annual time series data. Coverage is not complete for all years, countries and sectors in these databases.</timePrd>         <nation>Multi-nation</nation>         <geogUnit>Countries</geogUnit>         <anlyUnit>Administrative units (geographical/political)</anlyUnit>         <universe>Cross-national; National</universe>         <universe>The <i>UNIDO Industrial Statistics Databases</i> cover a number of countries listed on the <a class="external" href="http://www.unido.org/Data1/Statistics/Databases/ISAV.cfm?dig=2" title="INDSTAT2">INDSTAT2</a> and <a class="external" href="http://www.unido.org/Data1/Statistics/Databases/ISAV.cfm?dig=4" title="INDSTAT4">INDSTAT4</a> data availability webpages.</universe>         <dataKind>Numeric data</dataKind>         <dataKind> Aggregate (macro) level</dataKind>       </sumDscr>     </stdyInfo>     <method>       <dataColl>         <timeMeth>Time Series</timeMeth>         <timeMeth>annual. These data are updated annually.</timeMeth>         <sampProc>See the <a href=http://ukdataservice.ac.uk//use-data/guides/dataset/industrial-statistics.aspx>dataset user guide</a> for details.</sampProc>         <collMode>Four major sources have been used in compiling and cleaning the data contained in the UNIDO database:<br>i) industry data reported in country questionnaires<br>ii) national publications for industrial censuses, annual surveys and input-output tables<br>iii) international sources, both published and unpublished<br>iv) national data compiled by statisticians engaged by UNIDO to work in specific countries<br>Furthermore, the data have been supplemented with UNIDO estimates. <br>Data for OECD member countries are collected by OECD through OECD/UNIDO joint country questionnaires and provided to UNIDO for inclusion in the database.</collMode>         <sources />         <weight>Weighting used.  See documentation for details.</weight>       </dataColl>     </method>     <dataAccs>       <setAvail>         <accsPlac>UK Data Service</accsPlac>       </setAvail>       <useStmt>         <specPerm>Restricted access</specPerm>         <contact><a href=http://www.ukdataservice.ac.uk/help/get-in-touch.aspx>Get in touch</a></contact>         <conditions>Title and ownership of the Industrial Statistics databases remain with UNIDO.<br>  UNIDO grants you the right to use the databases and associated materials for the purposes of education, teaching, distance learning, private study or research only. Unauthorised publication, distribution or commercial use is prohibited. You must treat these UNIDO databases and associated materials and any elements thereof like any other copyrighted materials.<br>  Applications for permission to reproduce all or part of these <i>UNIDO Industrial Statistics Databases</i> should be made to:<br> UNIDO<br>  P.O. Box 300<br> A-1400 Vienna, Austria<br> stat@unido.org</conditions>       </useStmt>     </dataAccs>     <othrStdyMat>       <relStdy>4752 UNIDO Industrial Demand-Supply Balance Database, 1990-2010 </relStdy>       <relStdy>6286 UN Comtrade database, 1962-2013 </relStdy>       <relPubl>   </relPubl>       <relPubl>   </relPubl>       <othRefs>Language Of Study Description: English</othRefs>       <othRefs>Language Of Study Documentation: English</othRefs>     </othrStdyMat>   </stdyDscr> </codeBook>
